title: How to speak more confidently and persuasively | Matt Abrahams (professor, speaker, author)
key_insights: 30-40% of growth experiments showing initial lift have no long-term impact after a year
Optimizing for churn can be counterproductive - focus on total cohort value over retention rates
Long-term holdout experiments (1-3 years) reveal true impact vs pull-forward effects
Absolute numbers often more valuable than conversion rates for growth teams
Core product teams can operate without KPIs if there's strong founder taste and vision
Reducing monetary friction unlocks valuable merchants who might otherwise give up
Cross-functional collaboration requires trust and shared quality standards
100-year thinking enables better short-term decision making

guest_background.current_role: VP of Product and Head of Growth at Shopify

topics_discussed: Collaboration between growth and core product teams
memorable_quotes: The plan is the plan until it's not
Most businesses do ultimately fail... but the folks who do go on to be successful will make that entire cohort work
It's actually almost always easier to just make it harder to do the thing right before your step in the funnel to increase your conversion rate
frameworks_mentioned: Absolute metrics vs conversion rate optimization
summary: Shopify's VP of Growth shares counterintuitive insights about long-term experimentation, why optimizing for churn can hurt growth, and how their unique organizational structure balances 100-year vision with tactical growth execution. The conversation reveals how many growth wins are actually just pull-forward effects that disappear over time.
